title: Michigan State, Mark Dantonio are in a five-alarm fire after latest blowout loss | Opinion
text:
CLOSE Analyzing the state of Michigan State football, after a 3rd straight blowout loss, this time to Penn State, 28-7, at Spartan Stadium, Oct. 26, 2019. Chris Solari and Graham Couch, Detroit Free Press

EAST LANSING, Mich. — The situation has reached a critical stage.

Michigan State football has lost three straight games by a combined score of 100-17 and pressure is mounting on MSU coach Mark Dantonio.

This isn’t just an annoying engine light blinking on a dashboard. This is five-alarm fire time. It’s one thing to lose to Ohio State, Wisconsin and Penn State. It’s another thing to get blown out by them.

“It is tough to win a football game when you turn it over,” Dantonio said, after Penn State’s 28-7 victory over the Spartans.

Actually, it’s tough to win a football game when you score just one touchdown, get a field goal blocked, give up four touchdown passes, average just 2.7 yards per rush, throw two interceptions, play horrendously on special teams and average 31 yards per punt.

Other than that, things are just peachy for the Spartans.

The root of the problem is Dantonio's stubbornness. He refused to change the coaching staff after last season. He simply moved around coaching assignments. And the Spartans offense has scored just one touchdown in their last two games.

“Football is a tough game,” Dantonio said. “Football is a highly complicated, yet basic game I would say. You can complicate it all you want, and it can be as basic as a guy catching a ball or protecting or throwing the ball. From my perspective, we need to execute better. There are things that we can do from a call situation. We've got a lot of the same plays that other people run as well. Timing and who to go to and those type of things, but we will look at everything, we'll address everything, but then on the flip side of things too."

WINNERS AND LOSERS: Week 9 led by Oklahoma, Ohio State

FOOTBALL FOUR: As Ohio State rolls and Oklahoma falls, Alabama and LSU ready for showdown

The Spartans have a bye week to try to regroup.

But that’s not exactly encouraging, considering recent history. The Spartans had a week off to prepare for Penn State after getting blown out at Wisconsin.

But the Nittany Lions crushed the Spartans.

Now, the Spartans have a week to get ready to play Illinois. And suddenly, playing against Illinois doesn’t seem so easy, after it showed fight against Michigan, then beat Wisconsin and Purdue.

Michigan State coach Mark Dantonio walks off the field after speaking to players at a timeout during the second half against Penn State at Spartan Stadium in East Lansing, Saturday, Oct. 26, 2019. (Photo: Junfu Han, Detroit Free Press)

Illinois plays Rutgers next week, which means it likely will have a three-game winning streak when it plays MSU.

What will happen if the Spartans lose to Illinois?

With Michigan on the horizon?

It tells you the state of the MSU program, that Illinois now seems scary for the Spartans.

That’s why this is critical.

“We have to get ourselves healed up,” Dantonio said. “We have a lot of guys who are banged up, nicked up; guys that haven't played. You got to try to get those guys back and you have to stay positive that we are 4-4 – that's the beauty in it, I guess, if there is any beauty there. The beauty is we're not 2-7, we're 4-4. We got to take that and try to build on those things and get ourselves ready for Illinois.

"The only way I know how to do that is like I said before — stay tough, stay tough-minded, stay positive; don't get negative on people, place blame and say it's your fault. Stay positive and build into people and keep grinding. That's the only way I've known how to do it and that's what we'll continue to do."

All kinds of questions are swirling around this program.

But in many ways, MSU can still control how this ends.

Dantonio can cool the critics if the Spartans beat Illinois and Michigan, which just beat down Notre Dame. Then, MSU finishes against Rutgers and Maryland.

So what would happen if MSU lost to Illinois and Michigan?

Yikes.

Like I said, this is critical.

“You have to play better; you can't beat yourself,” Dantonio said. “You have to execute. There are certain things when you play a good football team that you cannot do. ... I think as much as anything, recollect yourselves, stay positive with what we're doing. As difficult as everybody wants to say (it is) out there, you can't abandon ship right now – you can't do that."

The Spartans don’t seem to have a plan right now.

Dantonio looked like he was throwing stuff against the wall against Penn State, switching quarterbacks, hoping something would stick.

But nothing is working right now. The situation is dire.

And there are so many issues, spread across the entire team, that there are no easy fixes.

description: Michigan State football has a 3-game losing streak and pressure is mounting on coach Mark Dantonio. They have lost those  games by score of 100-17.
